ygData.subject: 3D HyperNEAT Substrates
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, Not sure if this has been discussed but I was thinking of implementing 3D substrates. The canonical HyperNEAT substrate I think is nodes arranged in layers

Subject: 3D HyperNEAT Substrates
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770313; y=hBhwi1q2Klv3c2kpoohFr8d8eyseXTbKaDjQVemiusgj8K2ITljo
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Hi,

Not sure if this has been discussed but I was thinking of implementing=
 3D substrates. The canonical HyperNEAT substrate I think is nodes arranged=
 in layers of lines on the cartesian plane, with each row having a distinct=
 position on the y-axis and the nodes within that row arranged along the x-=
axis. Hence the strength of a connection is a function of all four coords, =
weight =3D f(x1,y1,x2,y2).

Seems to me that many common tasks (such as pro=
cessing image data) require each layer to be a plane, so we could have node=
s in a plane occupying x/y axes and the planes/layers being distinguished b=
y the z axis. weight =3D f(x1,y1,z1,x2,y2,z2) and the original 'flat' subst=
rate can still be represented if necessary.

I'm intending to implement it =
like this - has anyone else implemented CPPNs this way? Are there any probl=
ems with this approach?

Thanks,

Colin.
